Thu, 12 May 2016 18:48:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2016/05/12/477528379/brazils-new-cabinet-has-no-women-drawing-social-media-backlash?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2016/05/12/477528379/brazils-new-cabinet-has-no-women-drawing-social-media-backlash?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world Brazil's first female president was suspended on Thursday, and the man replacing her quickly installed a new Cabinet that has no women.

]]> Lulu Garcia-Navarro Convoy Carrying Desperately Needed Aid Refused Entry To Besieged Damascus Suburb A U.N. official said Daraya was "probably the place in Syria where the greatest unmet needs exist." ]]> Merrit Kennedy In Polluted India, Negative Ion Necklaces Vow To Help You Breathe Easier In India, there is money to be made fighting air pollution. NPR examines one product geared towards the bad air: a negative ion necklace. Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:11 -0400 http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477836061/in-polluted-india-negative-ion-necklaces-vow-to-help-you-breathe-easier?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477836061/in-polluted-india-negative-ion-necklaces-vow-to-help-you-breathe-easier?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world In India, there is money to be made fighting air pollution. NPR examines one product geared towards the bad air: a negative ion necklace.

]]> Geoff Brumfiel Indian Auto Maker Balances Luxury With Global Sustainability The luxury brand Jaguar is now owned by an Indian car company, Tata. A drive through the Los Angeles hills in a super high-end convertible provides some insights into what a country's auto industry says about its role in the world. Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:11 -0400 http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835985/indian-auto-maker-balances-luxury-with-global-sustainability?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835985/indian-auto-maker-balances-luxury-with-global-sustainability?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world The luxury brand Jaguar is now owned by an Indian car company, Tata. A drive through the Los Angeles hills in a super high-end convertible provides some insights into what a country's auto industry says about its role in the world.

]]> Sonari Glinton Brazil's Senate Votes To Remove President Dilma Rousseff From Office Brazil's ousted President Dilma Rousseff describes the effort to impeach her as a coup. Stepping in to replace her is Vice President Michel Temer, who has named an all-male and all-white cabinet — this in a highly diverse nation in which 53 percent are Afro decedent. Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:11 -0400 http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835943/brazils-senate-votes-to-remove-president-dilma-rousseff-from-office?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835943/brazils-senate-votes-to-remove-president-dilma-rousseff-from-office?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world Brazil's ousted President Dilma Rousseff describes the effort to impeach her as a coup. Stepping in to replace her is Vice President Michel Temer, who has named an all-male and all-white cabinet — this in a highly diverse nation in which 53 percent are Afro decedent.

]]> Lulu Garcia-Navarro British Prime Minister Unveils Overhaul To Money Laundering Rules British Prime Minister David Cameron unveiled new rules to tamp money laundering at a summit in London Thursday, and he urged world leaders to do the same. But his announcement was overshadowed by a gaff. Cameron was overheard telling the Queen that Nigeria and Afghanistan are "fantastically corrupt." Leaders of both countries are attending the summit. Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477836047/british-prime-minister-unveils-overhaul-to-money-laundering-rules?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477836047/british-prime-minister-unveils-overhaul-to-money-laundering-rules?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world British Prime Minister David Cameron unveiled new rules to tamp money laundering at a summit in London Thursday, and he urged world leaders to do the same. But his announcement was overshadowed by a gaff. Cameron was overheard telling the Queen that Nigeria and Afghanistan are "fantastically corrupt." Leaders of both countries are attending the summit.

]]> Lauren Frayer Kenya To Close World's Largest Refugee Camp At Dadaab NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Aden Tarah, a resident of the Dadaab refugee camp, about Kenya's announcement that the camp will be closed, and the residents will be sent back to their countries of origin. Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477836040/kenya-to-close-worlds-largest-refugee-camp-at-dadaab?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477836040/kenya-to-close-worlds-largest-refugee-camp-at-dadaab?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Aden Tarah, a resident of the Dadaab refugee camp, about Kenya's announcement that the camp will be closed, and the residents will be sent back to their countries of origin.

]]> First Climbers Reach Mount Everest Summit Since Deadly Avalanches The first foreign climbers have reached the summit of Mount Everest for the first time in two years. NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Jamling Tenzing Norgay at base camp about the lasting impact of the avalanches of 2014 and 2015 on the climbers, industry and environment. Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835999/first-climbers-reach-mount-everest-summit-since-deadly-avalanches?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835999/first-climbers-reach-mount-everest-summit-since-deadly-avalanches?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world The first foreign climbers have reached the summit of Mount Everest for the first time in two years. NPR's Robert Siegel talks with Jamling Tenzing Norgay at base camp about the lasting impact of the avalanches of 2014 and 2015 on the climbers, industry and environment.

]]> Why Brazil's Government Shake-Up Matters To Americans NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Brian Winter, editor-in-chief of <em>Americas Quarterly</em>, about why what's happening in Brazil should matter to people in the U.S. Thu, 12 May 2016 16:30:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835950/why-brazils-government-shake-up-matters-to-americans?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/2016/05/12/477835950/why-brazils-government-shake-up-matters-to-americans?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world NPR's Ari Shapiro talks with Brian Winter, editor-in-chief of Americas Quarterly, about why what's happening in Brazil should matter to people in the U.S.

]]> Pope Francis Says He's Open To Studying Whether Women Can Be Deacons The pontiff says he is willing to create a commission on the issue. It could signal a turning point for the Roman Catholic Church, which does not allow women to serve in ordained ministry. Thu, 12 May 2016 15:58:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/05/12/477816171/pope-francis-says-hes-open-to-studying-whether-women-can-be-deacons?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/05/12/477816171/pope-francis-says-hes-open-to-studying-whether-women-can-be-deacons?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world The pontiff says he is willing to create a commission on the issue. It could signal a turning point for the Roman Catholic Church, which does not allow women to serve in ordained ministry.

]]> Merrit Kennedy The Goal Of These Soccer Players Isn't Just Scoring Goals Soccer Without Borders, which won a $250,000 grant this month, helps kids overcome past trauma by kicking it and flicking it. ]]> David LaGesse Can Oregano Fight Cow Belches — And Climate Change? Gassy cows account for a good deal of the methane — a powerful greenhouse gas — generated by livestock farming. Danish researchers think feeding cows oregano might help rein in the bovine burps. Thu, 12 May 2016 12:25:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2016/05/12/477699832/can-oregano-fight-cow-belches-and-climate-change?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2016/05/12/477699832/can-oregano-fight-cow-belches-and-climate-change?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world Gassy cows account for a good deal of the methane — a powerful greenhouse gas — generated by livestock farming. Danish researchers think feeding cows oregano might help rein in the bovine burps.

]]> Sidsel Overgaard Instead Of A Moment In The Sun, Brazil Faces A Perfect Storm The Summer Olympics in Rio were supposed to be a showcase for modern, prosperous Brazil. Instead, the country is suffering a national meltdown that will now include the president's impeachment trial. Thu, 12 May 2016 12:06:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2016/05/12/477773770/instead-of-a-moment-in-the-sun-brazil-faces-a-perfect-storm?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2016/05/12/477773770/instead-of-a-moment-in-the-sun-brazil-faces-a-perfect-storm?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world The Summer Olympics in Rio were supposed to be a showcase for modern, prosperous Brazil. Instead, the country is suffering a national meltdown that will now include the president's impeachment trial.

]]> Greg Myre Italy Becomes Last Western European Nation To Legalize Same-Sex Civil Unions The country's Parliament passed the bill despite opposition from the Catholic Church and conservative politicians. Rights advocates hailed the vote, but many hoped the legislation would go further. Thu, 12 May 2016 10:13:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/05/12/477780198/italy-becomes-last-western-european-nation-to-legalize-same-sex-civil-unions?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/05/12/477780198/italy-becomes-last-western-european-nation-to-legalize-same-sex-civil-unions?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world The country's Parliament passed the bill despite opposition from the Catholic Church and conservative politicians. Rights advocates hailed the vote, but many hoped the legislation would go further.

]]> Merrit Kennedy Brazil's President Suspended From Office By Senate Brazil's Senate voted overwhelmingly to try President Dilma Rousseff for alleged manipulation of the country's budget. She is now suspended as president as impeachment proceedings move forward. Thu, 12 May 2016 05:54:00 -0400 http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/05/12/477761956/brazils-president-impeached-by-senate-and-is-suspended-from-office?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/05/12/477761956/brazils-president-impeached-by-senate-and-is-suspended-from-office?utm_medium=RSS&utm_campaign=world Brazil's Senate voted overwhelmingly to try President Dilma Rousseff for alleged manipulation of the country's budget. She is now suspended as president as impeachment proceedings move forward.

]]> Camila Domonoske
